messageBody:
On Thu, May 10, 2001 at 03:03:47PM -0400, Mark Richards wrote:

> Is there any way to run multiple tests concurrently in one JUnit session?
> We currently have >250 tests and it takes a long time to run them
> sequentially, however some of the tests could be run concurrently without
> impacting correctness or performance. Does JUnit support this, and if not,
> would it be hard to add?
>

I am developing a tool called Joshua that facilitates the distributed execution
of test suites that adhere to the JUnit testing framework. There is
currently no public version of the tool. However, I am working on a public
version that will utilize the newest versions of Jini, JavaSpaces, JNLP, and
the newest JUnit 3.6. You can read a paper that I have published
at the International Conference and Exposition on Testing Computer Software
(TCS 2001) that discusses Joshua. I was specifically addressing the issue
of regression testing since my industry experience found the largest test
suites were created over time by this type of testing. You can find more
information at the following links:

Joshua Main Site (developing, but still somewhat bare):

http://cs.allegheny.edu/~gkapfham/research/joshua/index.html

"Automatically and Transparently Distributing the Execution of Regression
Test Suites" (among other papers):

http://cs.allegheny.edu/~gkapfham/research/publish/index.html

What is your schedule for needing a tool that supports the distributed
execution of test suites? Would you be willing to contribute your application
and its tests for an empirical analysis that I am conducting? Do you have
developers that are interested in contributing to the creation of Joshua?

[Incidentally, I have not used the ActiveTestSuite, but from reading the
JavaDoc, I can see that Joshua goes past what this class provides. The tool
offers the ability to execute the test suite on multiple machines instead of
just multiple threads on the same machine. However, the idea is conceptually
the same. I think that distribution across multiple machines could yield
more cost effectiveness, depending on the computation/communication ratio that
your test suites exhibit.]
